humanReadableSynopsis: FluTE is a stochastic model of the spread of influenza across a large population. Individuals in this model have realistic social contact networks, and transmission and infections are based on the current state of knowledge of the natural history of influenza. The model has been calibrated so that outcomes are consistent with the 1957/1958 Asian A(H2N2) and 2009 pandemic A(H1N1) influenza viruses.
publicationsAboutRelease: Chao DL, Halloran ME, Obenchain VJ, Longini IM Jr (2010) FluTE, a Publicly Available Stochastic Influenza Epidemic Simulation Model. PLoS Comput Biol 6(1): e1000656. (doi:10.1371/journal.pcbi.1000656)
title: FluTE

humanReadableSynopsis: FluOutlook is a web platform for the exploration of influenza forecasts.  It provides a visual interface to numerical forecasts of the current influenza season in North America and Europe through maps and charts. Activity data and forecasts are updated weekly, based on the reports of the official influenza surveillance systems in each country.
title: FluOutlook

humanReadableSynopsis: HyPhy is an open-source software package for the analysis of genetic sequences using techniques in phylogenetics, molecular evolution, and machine learning. It features a complete graphical user interface (GUI) and a rich scripting language for limitless customization of analyses. Additionally, HyPhy features support for parallel computing environments (via message passing interface) and it can be compiled as a shared library and called from other programming environments such as Python or R. HyPhy has over 8000 registered users and has been cited in over 900 peer-reviewed publications (Google Scholar). Continued development of HyPhy is currently supported in part by an NIGMS R01 award 1R01GM093939.
title: HyPhy

humanReadableSynopsis:
Skeeter Buster is a detailed model of Aedes aegypti populations, developed at NC State University by a team led by Fred Gould (Entomology Dept.) and Alun Lloyd (Mathematics Dept.)

It is a stochastic, spatially-explicit model that models cohorts of mosquitoes at a very fine spatial scale, down to the level of individual breeding sites for immature cohorts, or individual houses for adults. The biology of Ae. aegypti is described with great detail on the previously developed CIMSiM model (Focks et al., 1993). Skeeter Buster additionally includes a detailed genetic component, and can therefore model the genetics of Ae. aegypti populations, making it a crucial tool in the evaluation and development of genetic control strategies.
sourceCodeRelease: on request. E-mail info@skeeterbuster.net
title: Skeeter Buster

humanReadableSynopsis: Synthetic Populations and Ecosystems of the World (SPEW) is an open-source R package for creating synthetic populations and ecosystems for any geographic region in the world.  The resulting synthetic ecosystems provide data on both synthetic agents and households, their locations, and (for US agents) both school and workplace assignments.
documentation: Documentation for completed synthetic ecosystems [PDF]
title: spew

humanReadableSynopsis: The R-package outbreaker implements a Bayesian approach for reconstructing outbreak data from pathogen genome sequences. It also implements a tool for outbreak simulation.
publicationsAboutRelease: Jombart T, Cori A, Didelot X, Cauchemez S, Fraser C & Ferguson N (2014) Bayesian Reconstruction of Disease Outbreaks by Combining Epidemiologic and Genomic Data. PLoS Comput Biol 10(1): e1003457. (doi:10.1371/journal.pcbi.1003457)
title: outbreaker

humanReadableSynopsis: PhyML is a phylogeny software based on the maximum-likelihood principle. Binaries are available for Linux, MacOS and Windows; the source code is available on request.
publicationsAboutRelease: "New Algorithms and Methods to Estimate Maximum-Likelihood Phylogenies: Assessing the Performance of PhyML 3.0." Guindon S., Dufayard J.F., Lefort V., Anisimova M., Hordijk W., Gascuel O. Systematic Biology, 59(3):307-21, 2010. (doi:10.1093/sysbio/syq010)
title: PhyML
GLEAM
humanReadableSynopsis:
GLEAM (GLobal Epidemic and Mobility Model) produces realistic simulations of the global spread of infectious diseases. It integrates three layers: real-world data on the global population; real-world data on the mobility of this population; an individual based stochastic mathematical model of the infection dynamics.

The GLEAM Simulator system consists of the GLEAM Server and the GLEAMviz Client application. The GLEAM Server uses GLEAM as the engine to perform the simulations. This server runs on high-performance computers managed by the GLEAM project. The GLEAMviz Client is a desktop application through which users interact with the GLEAM Server. It provides a simple, intuitive and visual way to set up simulations, develop disease models, and evaluate simulation results using a variety of maps, charts and data analysis tools.
documentation: GLEAMviz simulator client manual v6.7

developers: Commissioned by Sara de Valle Ph.D., Los Alamos National Labs
Programming by Software Development Service, Informatics Services Group.
humanReadableSynopsis: EpiCaseMap is a browser-based application that allows a user to visualize and compare spatio-temporal data (e.g. disease case data) as animated graphs and maps.  The software visualizes CSV data and data from the Project Tycho API.  Data are visualized as time-series graphs or animated maps (indicator-based and choropleths). The software can output the input data in JSON format.
title: EpiCaseMap

humanReadableSynopsis: Spew2synthia is a tool for translating the output of the SPEW synthetic ecosystem generator (SEG) into the output format of the Synthia SEG. SPEW is the successor to the Synthia SEG and provides several enhancements over Synthia including additional algorithmic methods for generating populations, options for placement of households, worldwide coverage and customized ecosystems through a native R library. The objective of this translation is to allow SPEW synthetic ecosystems to be used directly by Synthia-compatible disease transmission simulators such as FRED or pFRED. Translated results (Synthia synthetic ecosystems) are available on the Olympus Cluster and via the MIDAS Digital Commons (MDC).
title: spew2synthia
Apollo LS database - web app and API
humanReadableSynopsis:
The Apollo Location Service (LS) is a web service and user interface to the Apollo LS Database. The database issues persistent identifiers for locations for specific time intervals, including intervals that start in the past and are still open at present (i.e., the identifier should be used to refer to the location today). Temporally specific location identifiers are particularly important in epidemiology because the epidemiological record includes locations that do not presently exist, location names that have changed and location names whose political boundaries have changed. Users of the Apollo Location Service can search by Apollo LS identifier or location name.

MIDAS developers will find this web service useful for obtaining a persistent location identifier for use in datasets or software. They may also find useful the ability to retrieve GeoJSON data for any locations stored in the Apollo LS database so they can render a map in their software.

title: Project Tycho Repository - web app and API
humanReadableSynopsis:
The API to the Project Tycho Repository retrieves weekly case counts for a range of notifiable conditions in the US at the state or city level for time periods between 1888 and 2014.

The Project Tycho web application retrieves weekly case counts for a range of notifiable conditions in the US at the state or city level for time periods between 1888 and 2014.

The API and web application retrieve the same information.

title: RxNorm API
humanReadableSynopsis:
The RxNorm API is a web service for accessing the current RxNorm data set.

MIDAS developers will find this web service useful when working with data that is encoded using the RxNorm coding system or when standardizing datasets.

title: Entrez Programming Utilities (E-utilities)
humanReadableSynopsis:
The Entrez Programming Utilities (E-utilities) is a web service which allows you to execute text searches on the PubMed database of biomedical literature and 38 other literature and molecular databases including DNA and protein sequence, structure, gene, genome, genetic variation and gene expression.

An example of a use that MIDAS developers might make of this system is querying the NCBI Taxonomy Database for standard codes for host and pathogen species.

title: MedlinePlus Connect
humanReadableSynopsis:
MedlinePlus Connect is a web service for looking up codes used in the field of health care, namely ICD-9, ICD-10, SNOMED-CT, RXCUI, NDC and LOINC codes.

MIDAS developers will find this web service useful when working with data that is encoded using any of the coding systems listed above.

title: Epi-Data API
humanReadableSynopsis:
DELPHI’s Epi-Data API is a web service for looking up Influenza and Dengue data for the United States and Taiwan.

The service connects to several Influenza data sources that provide ILI counts and estimates, and Wikipedia page hits for ILI related articles. Dengue case counts are available for Taiwan.

MIDAS developers will find this web service useful as a single point of access to the several web services supported by the API.

The ComputationaL ARthropod Agents (CLARA) is a Netlogo agent-based model for vector-borne diseases. CLARA is still under development.

This DTM can be run from the command line of the Olympus Cluster. Note that an account is required. For information on how to register for an account on Olympus please click here.
title: CLARA

humanReadableSynopsis: This agent-based dengue model represents movement of and transmission dynamics among people and mosquitoes in Yucatán, Mexico, and simulates various vaccine scenarios to evaluate effectiveness under those conditions. It comprises 1.8 million people between 375,000 households and 100,000 workplaces and schools.
publicationsThatUsedRelease: Thomas J. Hladish, Carl A. B. Pearson, Dennis L. Chao, Diana Patricia Rojas, Gabriel L. Recchia, Héctor Gómez-Dantés, M. Elizabeth Halloran, Juliet R. C. Pulliam, Ira M. Longini (2016) Projected Impact of Dengue Vaccination in Yucatán, Mexico. (doi:10.1371/journal.pntd.0004661)
title: Dengue transmission model

humanReadableSynopsis:
Repository for Bellan et al. (2015). The statistical power and validity of Ebola vaccine trials in Sierra Leone: A simulation study of trial design and analysis. Lancet Infectious Diseases.

This disease transmission model (DTM) can be run using the Universal Interface to Disease Simulators available here.
publicationsThatUsedRelease: Bellan SE, Pulliam J, Pearson C, Champredon D, Fox S, Skrip L, Galvani AP, Gambhir M, Lopman BA, Porco TC, Meyers LA, Dushoff J (2015) The statistical power and validity of Ebola vaccine trials in Sierra Leone: A simulation study of trial design and analysis. Lancet Infect Dis 15:703-10 (doi:10.1016/S1473-3099(15)70139-8)
title: Ebola transmission model

humanReadableSynopsis: FRED (A Framework for Reconstructing Epidemiological Dynamics) is an open source modeling system developed by the University of Pittsburgh Public Health Dynamics Laboratory in collaboration with the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center and the School of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University.
title: FRED

humanReadableSynopsis:
A simulator of malaria epidemiology and control.

This DTM can be run from the command line of the Olympus Cluster. Note that an account is required. For information on how to register for an account on Olympus please click here.
title: Open Malaria

humanReadableSynopsis:
A simulator of malaria epidemiology and control.

This DTM can be run from the command line of the Olympus Cluster. Note that an account is required. For information on how to register for an account on Olympus please click here.
title: Open Malaria

humanReadableSynopsis: A simulator of malaria epidemiology and control.
title: Open Malaria

humanReadableSynopsis: The Global Epidemic Simulator is a platform for modelling directly transmissible human diseases such as influenza, and testing intervention policies that may reduce the duration or severity of an outbreak of such a disease. Building on previous work, this model is spatial and individual-based, using various geographical and demographic data sources to place households at absolute locations, populated with individuals of specific ages who each attend schools or workplaces situated in their vicinity. The significant advance of this project over previous work is the global nature of simulation, the memory and performance requirements of which motivate us towards a multi-core, multi-computer solution.
title: Global Epidemic Simulator

humanReadableSynopsis: Repast Simphony is a richly interactive and easy to learn Java-based modeling system that is designed for use on workstations and small computing clusters.
title: Repast Simphony

humanReadableSynopsis: Repast for High Performance Computing is a lean and expert-focused C++-based modeling system that is designed for use on large computing clusters and supercomputers.
title: Repast for High Performance Computing

humanReadableSynopsis: TranStat is a software application designed to estimate the transmissibility of infections within groups of individuals.
developers: Center for Inference and Dynamics of Infectious Disease
title: TranStat

humanReadableSynopsis: This web application uses a data-driven global stochastic and spatial vector-host epidemic model to provide a quantitative analysis of the spreading pattern of ZIKV in Latin America. The model divides the world population into geographic census areas that are defined around transportation hubs and connected by mobility fluxes. The model integrates real world demographic and transportation data.  It also consider the dependence with local weather data of ZIKV transmission drivers such as the mosquito lifespan and abundance. The basic calibration of the model is performed by a Markov Chain Monte Carlo analysis of specific Zika outbreaks. The model generates microsimulations that provide stochastic ensemble output of possible epidemic evolutions, and statistical estimates of newly generated cases, importation events, probability of autochthonous transmission as a function of time. The number of potential microcephaly cases related to Zika is projected on the basis of the epidemic incidence by using a model-based approach used for French Polynesia.
title: ZIKA Modeling

humanReadableSynopsis: SEEDY is an R package that contains a suite of functions for the simulation, visualisation and analysis of bacterial evolution within- and between-hosts
executables: Windows binaries: r-devel: seedy_1.3.zip, r-release: seedy_1.3.zip, r-oldrel: seedy_1.3.zip
OS X El Capitan binaries: r-release: seedy_1.3.tgz
OS X Mavericks binaries: r-oldrel: seedy_1.3.tgz
title: SEEDY

humanReadableSynopsis: nextflu v1.0 is the release of the Nextstrain project described in a 2015 Bioinformatics article. Nextstrain is an open-source project to harness the scientific and public health potential of pathogen genome data. We provide a continually-updated view of publicly available data with powerful analytics and visualizations showing pathogen evolution and epidemic spread. The goal is to aid epidemiological understanding and improve outbreak response.
publicationsAboutRelease: Neher, R. A., & Bedford, T. (2015). nextflu: real-time tracking of seasonal influenza virus evolution in humans. Bioinformatics, 31(21), 3546–3548. http://doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/btv381
title: nextflu

humanReadableSynopsis: Nextstrain is an open-source project to harness the scientific and public health potential of pathogen genome data. We provide a continually-updated view of publicly available data with powerful analytics and visualizations showing pathogen evolution and epidemic spread. Our goal is to aid epidemiological understanding and improve outbreak response.
title: nextstrain organization

humanReadableSynopsis: Galapagos is a web application for comparing and exploring the output of epidemic simulations.  The simulator output must be written in Galapagos format and provided as either a CSV or HDF5 file.  The application enables an analyst to quickly visualize simulator output in the form of tables of various statistics, graphs, and maps. Output from multiple simulations can be loaded into the tables and graphs, which allows an analyst to quickly compare the results of multiple simulations.  The user can download graphs in PNG, SVG, or PDF format, and can download tables in CSV format.
developers: Software Development Service, Informatics Services Group
title: Galapagos

humanReadableSynopsis: EpiVis is an interactive web application for visualizing epidemiological time-series data. The application visualizes data from the Epi-Data web service, which connects to several data sources that provide counts and estimates obtained and/or derived from primary sources such as ILINet, Google Flu Trends, and Wikipedia accesses. EpiVis can also visualize any data that users upload to the application in the form of a CSV file.
title: EpiVis

humanReadableSynopsis: ILI Nearby is a web application that displays real-time estimates of the prevalence of Influenza-like-illness activity at various administrative levels in the US. The analytic method is based on sensor fusion theory, which allows inference from multiple data sources.
title: ILI-nearby

humanReadableSynopsis: An R package that implements methods for anticipating the emergence and eradication of infectious diseases from surveillance time series. Also provides support for computational experiments testing the performance of such methods.
title: spaero: Software for Project AERO

humanReadableSynopsis: Delphi's forecasts are derived from expert's forecasts. To sign up to participate as an expert go to: http://delphi.midas.cs.cmu.edu/epicast/
title: Delphi

humanReadableSynopsis: This beta website houses the weekly influenza activity forecasts provided by eight research teams. It’s important to note that these are not CDC forecasts and that the forecasts on this website are not endorsed by CDC. These forecasts are based on different models, can vary significantly, and may be inaccurate.
forecasts: Short term (1-, 2-, 3-, and 4-week ahead) forecasts of weekly percent visits to sentinel clincians for ILI
title: FluSight: Seasonal Influenza Forecasting

humanReadableSynopsis:
Flusight is a static influenza forecasts visualizer. It takes weekly prediction files in the format used by CDC FluSight Challenge, extracts entities needed for visualization and generates a minified webpage ready for static hosting. The visualizer uses an intermediate file, summarizing the predictions, which can be generated either by the set of scripts in the repository (which uses CDC's prediction format) or by the user.

A live version associated with this github repository at http://reichlab.io/flusight/ displays predictions for CDC FluSight Challenge by Reich Lab at UMass Amherst. To know more about it, go to the about page in the wiki.
title: FluSight

humanReadableSynopsis: This web application displays (1) the weekly Influenza Like Illness (ILI) in US cities reported throughout an influenza season, and (2) detailed ILI forecasts.
forecasts: Weekly count of observed influenza like illness
title: Columbia Prediction of Infectious Diseases

humanReadableSynopsis: The Dengue Forecasting Project is a collaboration of several departments in the U.S. Federal Government (Department of Health and Human Services, Department of Defense, Department of Commerce, and the Department of Homeland Security), with the support of the Pandemic Prediction and Forecasting Science and Technology Interagency Working Group under the National Science and Technology Council. Its goal is to design an infectious disease forecasting project with the aim of galvanizing efforts to predict epidemics of dengue.This interagency project will assess forecasts using historical data from Iquitos, Peru and San Juan, Puerto Rico. On this webpage you can find the forecast targets, dengue data, environmental data, submission procedure evaluation criteria, and a detailed description of the project. Information about dengue is available from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).Any updates will be posted here and on the the NOAA Dengue Forecasting Page where these materials are also available. For submissions or questions about the project contact predict@cdc.gov.
forecasts: Total number of dengue cases in a transmission season
title: Dengue Forecasting Project

humanReadableSynopsis:
A version of FRED forked by the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center that works with the Apollo Web Services.

This disease transmission model (DTM) can be run using the Universal Interface to Disease Simulators available here.

This DTM can also be run from the command line of the Olympus Cluster. Note that an account is required. For information on how to register for an account on Olympus please click here.
title: pFRED

humanReadableSynopsis:
A version of FluTE forked by the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center that supports simulating over the whole US population and works with Apollo Web Services.

This disease transmission model (DTM) can be run using the Universal Interface to Disease Simulators available here.

This DTM can also be run from the command line of the Olympus Cluster. Note that an account is required. For information on how to register for an account on Olympus please click here.
title: Apollo FluTE

humanReadableSynopsis: This software installs the FRED simulator on a Windows 64-bit operating system.
title: FRED Windows 64

humanReadableSynopsis: This model projects Zika virus infections in childbearing women in the Americas.
publicationsThatUsedRelease: Perkins TA, Siraj AS, Ruktanonchai CW, Kraemer MUGK, Tatem AJ. (2016) Model-based projections of Zika virus infections in childbearing women in the Americas. Nature Microbiology 1:16126. (doi:10.1038/nmicrobiol.2016.126)
title: Zika virus infections in childbearing women in the Americas

humanReadableSynopsis:
The Dynamic Mosquito Simulation Model (DyMSiM) enables the simulation of mosquito populations driven by climate data. DyMSiM provides a useful tool for researchers investigating a number of mosquito-borne diseases.

DyMSiM was created using STELLA 9.02 software. You must have STELLA installed on your computer to run DyMSiM.
publicationsAboutRelease: Morin C and Comrie AC, 2010. Modeled response of the West Nile virus vector Culex quinquefasciatus to changing climate using the dynamic mosquito simulation model. International Journal of Biometeorology 54,517-529. (doi:10.1007/s00484-010-0349-6)
title: Dynamic Mosquito Simulation Model (DyMSiM)

humanReadableSynopsis: NetLogo is a multi-agent programmable modeling environment. It is used by tens of thousands of students, teachers and researchers worldwide. It also powers HubNet participatory simulations. It is authored by Uri Wilensky and developed at the CCL. You can download it free of charge.
title: NetLogo

humanReadableSynopsis: NetLogo is a multi-agent programmable modeling environment. It is used by tens of thousands of students, teachers and researchers worldwide. It also powers HubNet participatory simulations. It is authored by Uri Wilensky and developed at the CCL. You can download it free of charge.
title: NetLogo

identifier.identifierDescription: hospitalization with administration of intravenous antibiotics

humanReadableSynopsis:
An anthrax compartmental model developed by the University of Pittsburgh. The model is based on the model described in the paper: The Cost-Effectiveness of Strategies to Reduce Mortality From an Intentional Release of Aerosolized Anthrax Spores (RS Braithwaite et al)

The model supports the following control strategies: antibiotic prophylaxis of susceptible individuals in the population, hospitalization with administration of intravenous antibiotics to symptomatic individuals, and treatment in the I.C.U. for fulminant individuals.

This disease transmission model (DTM) can be run using the Universal Interface to Disease Simulators available here.

This DTM can also be run from the command line of the Olympus Cluster. Note that an account is required. For information on how to register for an account on Olympus please click here.
title: Pitt-Anthrax model

humanReadableSynopsis:
A SEIR compartmental model developed by the University of Pittsburgh. The model supports antiviral and vaccination control strategies.

This disease transmission model (DTM) can be run using the Universal Interface to Disease Simulators available here.

This DTM can also be run from the command line of the Olympus Cluster. Note that an account is required. For information on how to register for an account on Olympus please click here.
title: Pitt-SEIR model

humanReadableSynopsis: PHYLogeny Inference Package (PHYLIP) is a free computational phylogenetics package of programs for inferring evolutionary trees (phylogenies). It consists of 35 portable programs, i.e., the source code is written in the programming language C. Releases occur as source code, and as precompiled executables for many operating systems including Windows (95, 98, ME, NT, 2000, XP, Vista), Mac OS 8, Mac OS 9, OS X, Linux (Debian, Red Hat); and FreeBSD from FreeBSD.org. Full documentation is written for all the programs in the package and is included therein.
developers: Professor Joseph Felsenstein, of the Department of Genome Sciences and the Department of Biology, University of Washington, Seattle.
title: PHYLIP

humanReadableSynopsis: The Synthetic Microdata Household Viewer is a browser-based application that displays distributions of households in a synthetic (simulated) population generated from 2010 U.S. Census and 2007-2011 5-year American Community Survey data.  The software displays the distributions on interactive maps, and can show four demographic variables: household income, household size, householder race, and householder age.
title: Synthetic Microdata Household Viewer

humanReadableSynopsis: North American Animal Disease Spread Model (NAADSM) is a framework for creating stochastic, spatial, state-transition simulation models of the spread and control of highly contagious diseases of animals. User-established parameters define model behavior in terms of disease progression; disease spread by animal-to-animal contact, contact with contaminated personnel or equipment, and airborne dissemination; and the implementation of control measures such as vaccination and depopulation. Resources available to implement disease control strategies are taken into consideration. The model records a wide variety of measures of the extent of simulated outbreaks and other characteristics. The graphical interface and output visualization features also make it a useful tool for training and preparedness exercises. NAADSM has been developed with broad international support, and has been used to evaluate outbreak scenarios and potential control strategies for economically important animal diseases in many countries around the world.
documentation: Reeves A, Hupalo R, Patyk KA, Hill AE: The North American Animal Disease Spread Model: A simulation model to assist decision making in evaluating animal disease incursions (2012)
executables: Windows, Unix, and Mac OS executables can be found here
publicationsThatUsedRelease: Cozzens T, Gebhardt K, Shwiff S, Lutman M, Pedersen K, et al.: Modeling the Economic Impact of Feral Swine-Transmitted Foot-and- Mouth Disease: A Case Study from Missouri (2010)
Dube C, Ribble C, Kelton D, McNab B, Javier S, et al.: Network analysis of livestock movements to estimate potential silent spread of Foot-and-Mouth Disease (2008)
Dube C, Sanchez J, Reeves A: Adapting existing models of highly contagious diseases to countries other than their country of origin (2011)
Dube C, Stevenson MA, Garner MG, Sanson RL, Corsdo BA, et al.: A comparison of predictions made by three simulation models of foot-and-mouth disease (2007)

Ketusing N, Reeves A, Portacci K, Yano T, Olea-Popelka F, et al.: Evaluation of strategies for the eradication of Pseudorabies virus (Aujeszky's disease) in commercial swine farms in Chiang-Mai and Lampoon Provinces, Thailand, using a simulation disease spread model (2011)
Reeves A, Salman MA, Hill AE: Approaches for evaluating veterinary epidemiological models: verification, validation and limitations (2011)
Pendell DL, Leatherman J, Schroeder TC, Alward GS: The Economic Impacts of a Foot-And-Mouth Disease Outbreak: A Regional Analysis (2007)

Patyk KA, Helm J, Martin MK, Forde-Folle KN, Olea-Popelka FJ, et al.: An epidemiologic simulation model of the spread and control of highly pathogenic avian influenza (H5N1) among commercial and backyard poultry flocks in South Carolina, United States (2013)
Dillon E, Matthews A, Thorne F: Foot-and-Mouth Disease control costs compared: An Irish case study (2007)
title: NAADSM

developers: Software Development Service, Informatics Services Group
humanReadableSynopsis: The Apollo Library is a curated collection of infectious disease-related information gathered from health reports and other peer-reviewed sources.   All information in the library is available in both human and machine readable formats.
title: Apollo Library Viewer

humanReadableSynopsis:
Epidemic case count data are an important source of information for infectious disease researchers, but these counts are often distributed by health agencies in non-standard formats. Analysts typically spend a lot of time reformatting or “munging” these data before they can conduct their analysis.

We created Omnivore, a web-based tool for converting case count reports from health agencies into a standard data format. Omnivore, which is still under development, uses custom-developed parsers to automatically ingest data from various sources that include: Zika data from the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and Chikungunya data from the Pan American Health Organization, the Mexican Ministry of Health, and the Colombian Ministry of Health.

Omnivore automatically detects the data format and automatically extracts information such as the type of case counts (e.g. cumulative vs. intervals), report dates, and location. Omnivore automatically detects missing counts and duplicate counts, flagging missing counts removing duplicates after detection. Omnivore is currently undergoing final testing and will be a valuable tool to help researchers and practitioners to significantly speed up their workflow for analysis of epidemic time series data.
title: Omnivore
Climate Data Online: Web Services
humanReadableSynopsis: NCDC's Climate Data Online (CDO) offers web services that provide access to current data. This API is for developers looking to create their own scripts or programs that use the CDO database of weather and climate data. An access token is required to use the API, and each token will be limited to five requests per second and 10,000 requests per day.

title: HIV-TRACE
humanReadableSynopsis: HIV TRACE is a tool that aids in understanding how HIV is spreading among infected individuals through reconstruction and analysis of HIV-1 molecular transmission networks.
publicationsThatUsedRelease: Rose Rebecca, Lamers Susanna L., Dollar James J., Grabowski Mary K., Hodcroft Emma B., Ragonnet-Cronin Manon, Wertheim Joel O., Redd Andrew D., German Danielle, and Laeyendecker Oliver. AIDS Research and Human Retroviruses. March 2017, 33(3): 211-218. (doi:10.1089/aid.2016.0205)
